description: From earlier East Anglian dialectal dallop (“patch, tuft (of grass, etc.)”), of unknown origin. Compare dialectal Norwegian dolp (“lump”).

entries.meaning: A considerable lump, scoop, or quantity of something, especially soft food. [from 1810s]
examples: Each pancake comes with a dollop of suspiciously soft butter in a tiny plastic cup.

verbs.description: dollop (third-person singular simple present dollops, present participle dolloping, simple past and past participle dolloped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To apply haphazardly in generous lumps or scoops. [from 1820s]
examples: She dolloped a generous quantity of mustard on her hot dog.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To dole out in a considerable quantity; to drip in a viscous form.
examples: "It's fah-bu-lous to have these early salads, from the greenhouse, but don't they make you just long for summer?" Cath says to no one in particular as she dollops away generously onto plates.
